What is the next truth-functional connective to be introduced after conjunction?

The next truth-functional connective to be introduced after conjunction is disjunction. In later sections, it will be learned how to form complex propositions using various combinations of each of the four truth-functional connectives.

For example, we could represent the statement “Cincinnati is the capital of Ohio” using the capital letter C, which is called a constant. In propositional logic, a constant is a capital letter that represents an atomic proposition. In that case, we could represent the statement “Cincinnati is not the capital of Ohio” like this:   ~C  Likewise, we could represent the statement “Toledo is the capital of Ohio” using the constant T. In that case, we could represent the statement “Toledo is not the capital of Ohio” like this:  ~T  We could also create a sentence that is a conjunction of these two negations, like this:  ~C ⋅ ~T  Can you figure out what this complex proposition says?
